This Government is destroying both personal and corporate initiatives. If you ask a number of people why they are taking more time off and why they are not working as much overtime as they used to work, the answer is inevitably the same-'it is not worth our whUe to work overtime; it is not worth our while to work a Uttle bit harder, it is not worth our whUe to invest more money in a particular undertaking which we seek to pursue'. The simple reason is that the rate of taxation which they have to pay on any income which accrues is prohibitive. As I have said, this is destroying both individual and corporate initiative. Whether we Uke it or not, even the Deputy Prime Minister has recently come to the conclusion that we need a private sector within Australia and that if we are to have a continued viable private sector it must have some hope, some opportunity, some initiative left to it to enable it and to encourage it to invest, capitalise and seek expansion. Under the present taxation rates, both corporate and personal, this initiative, to- this encouragement, simply will not come about and the whole community will suffer. We see other areas where this is also occurring. The Government has decided to limit to $300 the amount of taxation deduction for rates and taxes. It thinks that people who have to pay more than

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 11 o'clock the House stands adjourned until 10 a.m. tomorrow. House adjourned at 11 p.m. The following answers to questions were circulated: Overseas Students: Medical Courses

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The honourable member for Deakin, Mr Jarman, in the Adjournment Debate on 27 February 1975 raised several questions concerning two private students from Malaysia upon notice: who entered the Methodist Ladies College, Kew, Victoria, with student visas from the Department of Immigration at the commencement of 1973 with the aim of obtaining their Higher School Certificates m 1974 and subsequently medical course. I have made preh'minary inquiries into matters raised. My Department was advised in October 1974 that Monash University was makreply ing some policy changes in relation to the ad- * P. c - ^ j ^ . ^ i . mission Of private overseas Students Ulto the medical course which would make it more cable difficult for these students to be accepted. I have asked my Department to seek further background on the University's decision, so that the information can be used in guidance to Australia's overseas posts for the future. Regular bnefing is provided to the Australian overseas posts on admission requirements of j e Austrahan educational institutions for overseas y levels students. I have asked my Department to ensure i. u - - r {- - i ^ that this bnefing information is kept as as possible However, the information on changes in the medical course at Monash was not ry levels. avaUable when the five students mentioned by the honourable member who are now studying at the Methodist Ladies CoUege were interviewed overseas last June. , , . Where students are admitted to Australia for matriculation studies to be followed by a tertiary course, there is no guarantee given, implicit or otherwise, by the overseas posts that admission to the tertiary course will automaticaUy follow successful matriculation since admission is the prerogative of the institutions concerned. As I indicated on 27 February I believe that adequate notice be given by institutions of changes in their admission requirements, and my Department will be raising this particular issue with the Universities. I am now replying to the letters from the honourable member for Deakin and from the \ * . J . ^ T J* 11 i ^ , Methodist Ladies CoUege but unless the Umversity changes its decision I cannot see that there is anything I can do to help. Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable percent. member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) There were no ing research or making scientific surveys in Indonesia in or 1974. However, in this period preliminary investigations for, and planning of, an animal Amounts research centre to be established near Bogor in West Java. The aims of this centre are to improve the research capabili$ ties of Indonesian scientists and to carry out research into 84,434,138 both the production and efficiency in production of animal protein, with emphasis being given to meat and eggs. 18,380,604 Australia's contribution, in the form of construction assistance, research facilities, scientific and administrative staff 5,297 and the training of Indonesian scientists, is expected to extend over a ten year period and to cost about $9 million. Other CSIRO scientists made short visits to the Research Institute for Estate Crops to advise on laboratory techniques for measuring the nutritional requirements of rubber and other estate crops. Source: Calculated from information in 'Schools', Department of Housing and Construction: Mr Lynch asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice: What is the nature and extent of his Department's research into (a) co-operative housing and (b) medium density housing.

Speaker: Mr LES JOHNSON
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (a) The Ausualian Government has been financing cooperative housing on a substantial scale since 1956 by means of funds supplied to terminating Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. My Department maintains a close interest in the activities of these cooperative socieues and also undertakes a regular examination of co-operative developments in other parts of the world. We are currendy examining some of these developments, such as cost-rent societies income earners, in connection with the activities of the proposed Australian Housing Corporation. (b) Medium density housing is one of the main topics being handled by the Housing Research Branch of the new Division of Building Technology and Sociology in my Department This research project will be long term and comprehensive and will require an examination of alternative dwelling types and the effect of these different types on resident attitudes. Factors such as the net dwelling densities, the efficiency of land utilisation, the area of private open space and the provision of car parking will be taken mto account when making a comparison of costs between medium density housing and traditional low density housing The study will determine how these costs bear on the occupier, and how they bear on the community as a whole through the provision of services. in a study done in Norway, a comparison will also be made between what has actually been achieved in medium density developments, and what can be theoretically achieved. Speaker: Mr LES JOHNSON
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES

(2) If so, what requests from the Department of Health incinerators are outstanding at the present time. (3) When will incinerators be Alice Springs and Adelaide. Dean of Faculty of Social Adminisuation, Sydney University Nov. 74 35 Engineer with the Department of Housing and Construction, Dec. 74/Jan. 75 Perth, Western Australia Mr Charles Jones-The answer to the honour(Question No. 1500) able member's question is as follows: In relation to quarantine incinerators installed at airports(1) The Australian Government construction authority for quarantine incinerators is the Department of Housing and Construction. The Department of Transport has the financial responsibility. Previous to early 1972 the Department of Civil Aviation did provide funds for the construction of incinerators at airports. However, it is now considered that the responsibility for the disposal of such wastes rests with the Department of Health and the generators of the wastes. (2) The Department of Health is considering a new incincapable of destroying quarantine wastes for Perth Airport. The Depanment of Transpon has given technical assistance in the planning of this unit. The Minister for Health be in a better position to provide a target date for its colleague, the Minister completion. (3) There is no requirement for quarantine incinerators at Newcasde, Alice Springs and Adelaide Airports. Turning to Darwin, before the disaster caused by Cyclone Tracy a quarantine incinerator was in operation at the airpon but the installation did suffer considerable damage. Target dates for (Question No. 1510) the completion of repair work are not available. However, the temporary cessation of the vast majority of international traffic through this airpon, secondary facilities are being used to dispose of the small amount of quarantine authority for incinwastes generated. (4) It seems that it would be more satisfactory for the Defor panment of Health to have the responsibility for the provision and maintenance of quarantine incinerators at built at Newcasde, Darwin, airports. With regard to seaports, my Department is not the constructing authority for incinerators and questions relating to this area should be directed to my colleague, the Minister for Health. Speaker: Mr LES JOHNSON
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The answer to the right honourable member's question is as follows: (I ) and (2) Home Savings Grant Scheme. (3) To encourage and assist young married persons, and young widowed or divorced persons with dependent children, to buy or build their own homes, and to reward savings made towards that objective. (4) Briefly, to be eligible for a grant of up to $750, a son must(a) have married; (b) be under 36 years of age; (c) have contracted to buy or build, or have commenced to construct as an owner-builder, the person's first matrimonial or family $22,500; (d) have held savings in Australia for at least three years in an approved form before acquiring a home; and (e) be an Australian citizen, or a resident of Australia, for at least three years. (5) 20July 1964. (6) Homes Savings Grant Act 1964-1973. (7) (a) By distribuuon of the Departmental explanatory pamphlet 'A Grant for Your Home', and applicadon forms, which are available free of charge from banks, building socieues, post offices and offices of the Department; (b) by extensive publicity in the early years of the Scheme, and on each occasion the legislauon is amended; (c) by continued liaison with savings institutions and lending authoriues. (8) 1971-72 41,735 1972-73 47,260 1973-74 41,609 (9) The Secretary to the Depanment and officers holding delegated powers under the legislation. (10) 1971-72 92.1 percent 1972-73 91.2 percent 1973-74 92.2 percent (II ) 100 per cent. (12) and (13) Depanmental officers in each capital city are in daily contact either personally or in writing with appliprogram cants and prospective applicants, and with savings institutions and lending authondes, throughout Australia, to explain the requirements of the Scheme. (14) All reasonable efforts have been made to bring the existence of the scheme, the eligibility condidons and the applicadon procedures to the nouce of the community. (15) There is no requirement in the legislauon that the grant must be expended on the purchase or construction of the dwelling but, if the purchase or construction has not been completed at the time of application for the grant, ent of a grant must advise the construction is not subsequently completed. Checks are made in cases of doubt. (18) A Home Savings Grant may not be made in respect of a home purchased from a State housing authority (or from another person with the assistance of a loan from the authority) if the home was built or the purchase is financed with money provided under a Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement or if the terms of purchase are subsidised by reason of an Australian Government grant to the State under the States Grants (Housing) Act 1971-1973. Similarly, in the case of a home in the Australian Capital Territory or the perNorthern Territory, a grant is not payable if the home is purchased from, or with the aid of a loan from, the Australian Government or the Northern Territory Housing Commission. This is checked at the time of examining an application for a grant. Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The answer to the right honourable member's question is as follows: The following programs administered by my Department and the Commonwealth Sciendfic and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) enable individual groups or people in the community to apply for grants for a specific purpose. This information supplements that provided in my reply to Question on Notice No. 95 (Hansard, 5 December 1974, pages 4854-59). A. DEPARTMENT OF SCIENCE (1) Australian Research Grants-mad e in support of high level research projects by individuals and groups. (2) Australian Biological Resources Study-mad e for the study of the taxonomy, distribution and ecology of Australia's biological resources. (3) Crown of Thorns Starfish Research Grants-mad e for research into the problem caused by the crown of thorns starfish. (4) US/Australia Agreement for Scientific and Technical Co-operation-mad e to provide additional opportunities for the United States and Australia to exchange ideas, information, skills and techniques and to collaborate on thefieldof civil science. Details relating to the above programs may be found in the following 'documents published by the Australian Government Publishing Service: Department of Science. Report for the period 20 December 1972 to 30 June 1973. Department of Science Annual Report 1973-74. ARGC Report 1970-72. ARGC Grants approved for 1973. ARGC Grants approved for 1974. Australian Biological Resources Study Interim Council. Report 1973-74. US/Australia Agreement for scientific and technical co-operation. Report on activities to 30 June 1972. B. COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC and INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANIZATION (CSIRO) (1) Grants to research associations, e.g. Sugar Research Institute, Bread Research Institute of Australia. (2) Grants to other national bodies where support by the Australian Government is channelled through CSIRO, i.e. Standards Association of Australia (SAA) National Association of Testing Authorities (NATA) (3) Extra-mural grants to universities and similar bodies. (4) Grants from the Science and Industry Endowment Fund (SIEF). The purpose of these programs, which have been in operation for many years, is to foster and stimulate scientific research. They have as their authority the Science and Industry Research Act 1949-1973 and the Science and Industry Endowment Act 1926-1949. Grants under these programs are not pubUcised in detail each year but by reference to CSIRO Annual Reports and from for general knowledge within the scientific community, interested parties would be aware of the existence of these of money paid out for all programs. The amount paid under each program in each of the last three years is provided in the following table. 1971-72 1972-73 1973-74 $ $ $ Research Associations 372,517 454,984 531,905 Other National Bodies 830,800 935,800 1,142,900 Extra-mural Grants 76,878 73,876 78,404 SIEF Grants 9,408 8,901 26,288 Records of unsuccessful requests for grants are not maintained for thefirstthree programs and it is only in respect of SIEF grants that appUcations from individuals are considered. As shown in the table below (see (4) Science Industry Endowment Fund Grants) relating to these grants, the majority of SIEF grants are made to individuals. All appUcations for grants are considered by the Executive of CSIRO, acting either in that capacity or as Trustees of the Science and Industry Endowment Fund. In some cases it is necessary for the Executive to seek the approval of the Minister for Science and the Treasurer for grants to e.g., research associations. As CSIRO is represented on the managing boards of research associations, the SAA and NATA, it is in a position to influence decisions on the purposes for which grants are to be used. SimUarly CSIRO is able to assess the use of grants. In these and other cases, CSIRO receives annual reports covering both thefinancialand research aspects of the grants. problems of mutual interest in The Executive of CSIRO, through Uaison with other grant agencies, attempts to avoid any possibiUty of duplication of grants and, as an additional safeguard against this possibUity, applicants are required to state in their application whether funds have been sought from other sources. Further detaUs on each of these programs follow: (1) Grants to research associations. To be eligible the association must demonstrate that sufficientfinancialsupport is avaUable from industry for its establishment and operation and it must have as its objective the undertaking of scientific research and such associated activities as are approved by CSIRO. (2) Grants to other national bodies. The Standards Association of Australia and the National Association of Testing Authorities were formed as a result of pohcy of the Government of the day in the 1920's and 1940's respectively. The Standards Association of Australia brings together representatives of industry, commerce, government, the professions and other interested parties to develop detailed standards specifications and provides facilities for review and revision of standards fromtimeto time. The resulting standards are published in the 'Standards Association of Australia Monthly Information Sheet' and the 'Australian Standards Annual List of SAA PubUcations'. The National Association of Testing Authorities was estabUshed to organise a national service to provide testing facUities to meet the demands of Government, industry, and commerce and thus assist in maintaining the products of industry at a high standard. (3) Extra-mural Grants. These grants are made to support research in university departments and similar institutions when that research is of interest to CSIRO and can more profitably, both for CSIRO and the university, be pursued by taking advantage of the facilities and staff availability in the university concerned. (4) Science and Industry Endowment Fund Grants. There are no formal conditions attached to the grants, however the Executive of CSIRO, as Trustees of the Science and Industry Endowment Fund, allocates grants from the Fund to provide assistance: (a) to retired professional scientists, for individual work in an area in which they have demonstrated their competence and standing; (b) to gifted amateurs recognized by professional scientists as being competent workers in their field; and (c) for activiUes encouraging greater interest in scientific research among young people e.g. school science competitions. The Trustees rarely approve support from the Fund if assistance might be given by existing institutions (e.g. applications from members of staff of universities or other institutions having research as one of their functions). Some statistical details on the Fund for the last three years follow: Applications Applications 1971-72 . 17 1972-73 . 18 1973-74 . Total Grants 1971-72 6,476 1972-73 . 17,345 1973-74 . 37,394 Capital Fund for Aboriginal Enterprises Mr Snedden asked the Minister representing Question the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice: (1) Do the provisions of capital funds or other funds or grants schemes enable a non-Aboriginal spouse of an Aboriginal to receive money. (2) If so, under what conditions is approval given. (3) How many such approvals have been given in each of the last 5 years.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the right honourable member's question: (1), (2) and (3) The Aboriginal Enterprises (Assistance) Act 1968 provided for the Capital Fund Enterprises to extendfinancialassistance to enable persons of the Aboriginal race of Australia to engage in business enterprises that had prospects of becoming or continuing to be successful. A similar provision is included in the Aboriginal Loans Commission Act. When considering applications for financial assistance where one spouse was non-Aboriginal, the Capital Fund Advisory Committee's practice was to apply the following criteria: (a) If the breadwinner was Aboriginal and intended to be the main participant in the proposed enterprise the loan, if approved, was made to that breadwinner. (b) If the breadwinner was non-Aboriginal, careful consideration was given to the likely degree of involvement in the enterprise of the Aboriginal spouse.. Where it was considered that such involvement would be minimal, the applicants were advised that they were not eligible under the Act. In the event that such involvement was considered to be substantial, then the loan, if approved, was made to the couple as a partnership. Since January 1970, the Capital Fund for Aboriginal Enterprises provided 25 loans to partnerships where one spouse was not an Aboriginal. The break-up was as follows: 1970 5 1973 7 1971 7 1974 4 1972 2 Grant schemes administered by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs are applicable only to Aboriginal communities or groups. The question of a non-Aboriginal spouse of an Aboriginal receivingfinancialbenefit from these schemes Percentage does not therefore arise. Coal: Darling Downs (Question No. 1957) Mr MCVeigh asked the Minister for Minerals and Energy, upon notice: (1) What stage has been reached in the development of a hydrogenation plant to convert Darling Downs coal into fuel energy forms. Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The answer to the honourable M.B.F. Contribution Rates member's question is as follows: The present rate of inflauon is not 20 per cent, nor was it at Medical Medical Medical the time the honourable member's question was placed on and PubUc and Inter- and Private nodce. ward mediate ward The index used in Australia to measure the rate of inflation normaUy is the Consumer Price Index. To this end, the Australian Government has submitted to the full Bench of the ConcUiation and Arbitration Com$131.60 mission hearing the current national wage case that a form of $141.10 indexation of wages and salaries should be implemented and 7.2% that other grounds for wage and salary increases be limited. $158.20 Thefinaldecision in this matter rests, of course, with the 12.1% Commission. 20% Hutt River: Income Tax (Question No. 1970) Dr Klugman asked the Treasurer, upon notice: Has his attenuon been drawn to a statement by Leonard Casley, wheat farmer of Western Australia and self styled Prince Leonard of Hutt River, in which he claims that he and other resident citizens of Hutt River Province do not pay taxation on income earned totally within the Hutt River ince; if so, is the statement correct.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The answer to the honourdated able member's question is as follows: Contrary to the impression conveyed Casley, the so-called Hutt River Province has not seceded from Australia and has no legal status. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that there is no provision tax law under which persons residing in the Hutt River area of Western Australia may be granted exemption from tax on income arising from sources in that area. Morrison Rarotonga September-October 1974 Zambia: Australian Assistance (Question No. 1978) Mr Garland asked the Minister representing Provthe Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice: (1) With reference to the news release of the Minister 22 December 1974, how is it proposed to see that the payment of $150,000 to the African national liberation movements will be confined to humanitarian assistance for by Mr Leonard peoples in Zambia. (2) Is it a fact that the payment will make other funds in the income avaUable for violent purposes.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Australia's assistance of $150,000 will be provided to a United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) project in (Question No. 1977) Zambia. The project is of a humanitarian nature and involves provision of schools, health clinics, child care centres, training units and nutrition units for refugees from Southern Rhodesia, South Africa, Namibia and Angola who have temporarily setded in Zambia. Our confor tribution will be made avaUable to UNICEF which is refor the project and will ensure that donor contributions are spent for purposes for which they are intended. (2) An officer of the Australian Mission in Nairobi has sufficiently high representative the refugee camps in Zambia and his observations indicate that the support currendy given to the women and chUdren in these camps is extremely Umited. The Australian would therefore be used to fulfil a need not being currently met and would be most unlikely to release any funds for other purposes. Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The Public Service has provided the following answer to the right honourable member's question: (1) A consultative group representing staff was established in April 1973. (2) Access to specific information to be held in the DATA system about individuals will be made users of the system only on date' basis. This means that an authorised Public Service Officer will have access only to that information in the system which he needs to carry out his official duties. Design features will be incorporated equipment and also suitable procedures will be estabhshed to ensure that access is by authorised staff only and that access is on a restricted basis. In its operation of the MANDATA system the Board will of course have continuing regard for any general principles which may be established by the of individuals in respect of data held about them in computer systems. Mr Anthony asked the Minister for Minerals panel and Energy, upon notice: (1) Did he state on 17 September 1974 that the annual throughput of refineries in Australia was 220 million barrels of crude and liquids associated with crude. (2) Did he also claim that there of these liquids in reserve which by simple division gives Australia 15 years fuel reserves. (3) If so, does he adhere to these figures. (4) Do hisfiguresfor liquid reserves contain approximately 1000 million barrels of liquid petroleum gas. (5) Has he any estimate of the percentage of liquid reserves which are recoverable at the present Australian price of crude oil; if so, what are the details. (6) What is his projection of demand for refinery feedstock during each of the next 1S years. (7) Did the Forecast of Consumption 1972-73 to 1984-85 published by his Department state at page 3 that refinery feedstock demand will increase by 4.9 per cent per annum; if so, what is the reconciliation of estimate with thefigureshe gave on 17 September 1974, which imply constant annual demand. Mr Connor-The answer to therighthonourable member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) See Hansard of 17 September 1974 1263. (3) 1 adhere to what I then said. (4) About 900 million barrels of L.P.G. (5) Remaining liquid reserves recoverable from fields declared commercially viable aggregate about reserves whenfieldswhich have not yet been declared commercial or are awaiting connection to a pipeline are included. (6) Because of factors influencing future those I mentioned in my answer on 25 February to Question No. 917 (Hansard page 699), I am not prepared projections which would depend on too many assumptions to be of real value. (7) Yes. No reconciliation is necessary. In stating explicitly able on 17 September 1974 that 'At present day consumption rates Australia has 15 years of fuel supply in reserve', clearly implied that the life of the reserve would vary inverof sely with consumption rates. Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The answer to the honourable the answers to member's question is as follows: by that report but if, on reading 1 to 4. In all cases where tenders are invited for residential leases (single residential leases and leases for medium density housing) in the Australian Capital Territory, the followFuel Supplies ing procedures have and still continue to apply: (Question Na 2188) Tenders are invited and a closingtimeis nominated. A formally constituted departmental tender opening opens tenders immediately after the closing time. An Internal Auditor attends on a random basis. All tenders are opened at the same time. Occasionally tenderers bidding for a single site have submitted more than one bid. In all cases the highest bid is accepted. Where a number of leases are offered together appUcants can bid for one or aU of the available leases were 3300 million barrels indicating their order of preference and the number of sites sought. AppUcations are considered by the Departmental Tender Board which makes recommendations to the Permanent Head of the Department of the Capital Territory. The names of successful appUcants are notified in the Australian Government Gazette together with details of the lease purchased and the price paid. Company Taxation (Question No. 2195) Mr Bourchier asked the Treasurer upon of Primary Fuels notice: about (1) Has his attention been drawn to the statement by a this Professor Jones of the United Kingdom that the industrial decUne in that country is caused by massive company and direct taxes, which leave too Utde money for re-investment or expansion. (2) Can he say whether company tax in the United Kingdom is 19 per cent, in West Germany 27 per cent and in at page the United States of America 30 per cent. (3) Does the Government agree that the Australian tax charge of 45 per cent is too high under the present economic pressures. (4) Does the Government also agree that the private enterprise sector must be allowed to make a profit in order to 75 per cent of offer continuous employment. (5) Do taxes on profits at 45 per cent, in conjunction with high inflation rates, mean that residue profits are inadequate demand, like to permit required expansion. (6) Will he take urgent steps to reduce this tax rate until to make such time as inflation is reduced.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The answer to the honour member's question is as follows: (1)1I have seen statements by a number of persons attribu- . I ting the United Kingdom's economic problems to a variety quite difierent factors, including those mentioned by the honourable member. (2) Of the three countries referred to, only the United States has the same so-called classic system of company taxation as Australia. In the United States the general company tax rate is effectively 48 per cent on all income in excess of S2S,000 (a lower rate of 22 per cent applies on the first $25,000 earned). The Federal Republic of Germany has a split-rate system of taxing company profits under which undistributed profits are effectively taxed at 52.53 at 24.55 per cent. The United Kingdom has an imputation system of taxing companies and their shareholders under which a shareholder is permitted a credit against personal income tax on dividends received to allow for some of the tax paid by the distributing company on the profits it distributes. The credit is provided through what is known as advance corporauon tax, paid at the time a distribution is made, and set at a level equal to the basic rate of personal tax. From 1 April 1974, the rate of corporation tax has been 52 per cent and the basic rate of personal tax 33 per cent. (3) The present rate of tax on public companies is comparatively low in terms of recent experience. (4) Yes. (5) and (6) Questions relating to inflation and taxation, with respect to both companies and persons, are being studied by a Committee of Inquiry under the chairmanship of Professor R. Mathews. The report of the committee, to be submitted by May this year, will be most carefully considered by the Government. Mr Garland asked the Treasurer upon notice: (1) Did he write to Mr J. Mottram of Ajax Printing and Duplicating Pty Ltd, Thornbury, Victoria, on 10 June 1974 indicating that he thought the complications of metric measures are likely to confuse and distress persons much more than decimal currency and that he could not see that the benefits are immense. (2) Did he also say that he favoured acdon to suspend conversion so that its costs and benefits can be reassessed. (3) If so, was he expressing the atdtude of the Government; if not, what action is

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Title: ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) Yes. (3) No. My letter did not purport to express the Government's atdtude. My colleague the Minister for Science, who is the Minister responsible for the metric conversion gram, is aware of my personal views on the subject. Nitrogenous Fertilizer Mr MCVeigh asked the Minister for Minerals and Energy upon notice: (1) Is the supply of nitrogenous fertilizer to the tural industry threatened. (2) If so, is this caused by the knowledge that the operauons of Consolidated Fertilizers, Gibson Island (Brisbane) Plant are jeopardised because existing supplies of natural gas in the Roma Gas Field could be exhausted within 10 years. (3) What encouragement is the Australian Government giving in the way of provision of improved taxadon measures and other incentives for gas exploration and development of improved gas flow to the Gibson Island Plant. (4) Will he ensure that everything possible is done to make adequate supplies of nitrogen avadable on a continuing basis at reasonable prices. per cent and distributed profits Mr Connor-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Industries Assistance Commission concluded, in its repon of 16 July 1974 at page 15, that total Australian capacity of the nitrogenous fertilizer industry is 1.7 times the level of Australian market requirements for all uses and will not, it is estimated, be matched by Australian demand until 1980 at the earliest. (2) See(l). (3) and (4) The Pipeline Authority is consulting Queensland authorities concerning future supplies of natural gas to Brisbane with a view to reaching basic supply decisions this year and is in touch with the Queensland Government Gas Engineer and Chief Gas Examiner with a view to the early establishment of an authoritative assessment of probable long-term market demands so that the most economical solution can be found. Works of Art: Acquisitions (Question No. 1659) Metric Conversion Mr Snedden asked the Prime Minister, upon (Question No. 2196) notice: (1) What works of an have been purchased by the Government since 2 December 1972. (2) From whom were they bought and for what price. (3) What is the name, nationality and age of each of the artists whose works have been purchased. (4) What are the corresponding details for the equivalent period prior to 2 December 1972. (5) What percentage of purchases by the National Gallery Acquisitions Committee has been of Australian works of an in each of the last 5 years. he taking to change that atdtude. (6) What percentage of the total money expended in acquiring works of an has gone towards Australian works of an in each of the last 5 years.

text: The answer to therighthonourable member's question is as follows: (1) to (4) The right honourable member will know of my interest over many"years in this matter. I refer him to my proquesdons of 20 October 1964 (Hansard page 2126), 29 September 1965 (Hansard page 1475), 28 October 1966 (Hansard pages 2423-4), 8 November 1967 (Hansard pages 2869-70), 27 November 1968 (Hansard page 3375), 9 September 1969 (Hansard page 1013), 12 June 1970 (Hansard (Question No. 2218) page 3670), 21 October 1970 (Hansard page 2613), 24 February 1971 (Hansard page 624) and 23 November 1971 (Hansard page 3531) and my answers of 27 March 1973 (Hansard page 760), 13 December 1973 (Hansard pages agricul4778-84) and 5 December 1974 (Hansard pages 4829 and 4851-2). I would also draw the right honourable member's attention to the answer given by the then Prime Minister on 14 May 1970 to a question without notice (Hansard pages 2128-9) concerning the time and attention required of semor depanmental officers in answering questions on notice. He said, inter alia, "there can be no attempt to stop people asking questions to elicit information. That should be understood. But it should also be questions are placed on a notice paper then it will take a very long time to answer them . . . or it will tie up large numbers of public servants who .have other things to do . . . The problem is there; the solution is one of common sense and self discipline." : The very lengthy appendix to this answer lists, by artist and year of acquisition, works of art acquired for the Australian National GaUery from 1 July 1969 to 31 December 1974.
